headline: Tariff chaos underlines frustration between automakers, Trump
summary: After US President Donald Trump backed off on doubling tariffs on aluminum and steel imports from Canada, iSeeCars.com executive analyst Karl Brauer joins Asking for a Trend with Josh Lipton to discuss the impact of tariff uncertainty on automakers. Brauer tells Yahoo Finance while it is "possible" for automakers to make their cars entirely in the US, it wouldn't be "easy": "The problem isn't making them here. The problem is the transition to making them here." The analyst says that the difference between the long time it takes automakers to make that transition compared to the speed in which politicians can enact policies, like tariffs, is a source of frustration for the auto industry. Watch the video above to hear from the analyst about changes automakers can make, uncertainty under Trump policies, and more. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Asking for a Trend here. This post was written by Naomi Buchanan.

headline: Trump Pledges 50% Tariffs on Steel and Aluminum From Canada
summary: The U.S. will increase its planned 25% tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminum to 50%, President Trump said on Truth Social on Tuesday, in response to Ottawa’s retaliation to U.S. tariffs.  Trump added he would “substantially increase” levies on cars on April 2, which he said would “essentially, permanently shut down the automobile manufacturing business in Canada.”  Trump had pledged 25% tariffs on steel and aluminum from trading partners including Canada, effective March 12.
